column6: Disclosure Name
column9: Initiative from the undisclosed GRI (found by the coder but not mentioned in the GRI index table)

column6: Collective bargaining agreements
column7: Consultation requirements regarding notice periods for major operational changes are set by Modern Awards that apply to some of Stockland's people. Collective bargaining and Enterprise Agreements do not specify a minimum notice time frame. However, they state that change notice must be given as early as practicable.\t

column6: Process to determine material topics
column7: Stockland adopted the materiality definition from the International Integrated Reporting Framework to disclose information about matters that may substantively affect the organisation's ability to create value over the short, medium, and long term. The Leadership Team and Board review and disclose these key risks bi-annually.

column6: List of material topics
column7: Stockland's material topics are corporate culture, climate change, health, safety and wellbeing.

column6: Management of material topics
column13: Stockland's independently administered 'Our Voice' employee surveys provide regular opportunities for its people to share their feedback about working at Stockland and allow its leaders to listen and respond to that feedback. In FY23, Stockland significantly increased overall employee engagement, now eight points above the Australian National Norm and, for some categories, above the Global High Performing Norm.

column6: Management of material topics
column13: Based on customer data, Stockland's Communities successfully rolled out the Customer Service Centre (CSC), resulting in a 25% increase in sales team productivity and an improved customer journey. The initial data was piloted in FY22 and led to an expansion to all Masterplanned Communities and medium-density projects this year and, more recently, to the Land Lease Communities customers.
column20: Customer Service Centre, customer data, sales team productivity

column6: Management of material topics
column13: In November 2022, Stockland was recognised by the International WELL Building Institute (IWBI) as the first Australian property group to achieve a WELL Health_x0002_Safety Rating in the retail sector, obtaining a rating for eight of its shopping centres across New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, and Western Australia. The rating was achieved by working collaboratively with a team of contractors, consultants, facilities managers and retailers at each centre to assist Stockland in adopting strategies to support the health and well-being of Stockland customers and retailer staff.
column20: WELL Health-Safety Rating, IWBI, shopping centre

column6: Management of material topics
column13: In December 2022, Stockland launched The Stockland Hub to provide its customers with an enhanced and personalised digital experience across 22 of its Masterplanned communities. The Hub supports new digital enquiries and provides a streamlined engagement path for Stockland customers by personalising their experience based on their buyer type and guiding customers through the home buying and building process in a self-service digital portal.
column20: The Stockland Hub, digital experience, engagement path

column6: Management of material topics
column13: Stockland Terra, Stockland's proprietary and tailored geospatial analytical application, is improving how its teams explore, track, and evaluate land acquisition opportunities across Australia. In FY23, Stockland embedded its 'customer first' thinking into the Terra platform by surfacing demographic data for land corridors, allowing Stockland to understand the addressable market rapidly.
column20: Stockland Terra, geospatial analytical application, land acquisition

column6: Management of material topics
column13: In April 2021, Stockland launched the Customer Advocacy Group (CAG) and Customer Champion Groups (CCG) across its business units, demonstrating its commitment to driving and embedding a customer-centric culture that creates a superior customer experience, leveraging all levels of Stockland's business. These groups work with the business to prioritise and deliver initiatives and projects to enhance Stockland's customer experience and customer-centric culture. Starting with the customer, listening to and understanding different layers of feedback and data, the groups apply a customer-led lens to determine which projects will maximise customer satisfaction and create value for Stockland.
column20: Customer Champion Group, Customer Advocacy Group, customer-centric culture

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column7: Stockland generated $440 million in profits in 2023.

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: Stockland's climate resilience assessment methodology assesses the resilience of individual properties and communities. It focuses on the vulnerability of Stockland's assets to climate change, particularly its ability to endure severe weather impacts and operate without disruption. Key resilience criteria include location, design, structure, operation and maintenance, utilities and services, and stakeholders. The assessment of these components is combined to provide an overall climate resilience score on a scale of 1 to 25, from outstanding resilience to high vulnerability.
column20: Climate resilience assessment methodology, climate change, severe weather impact

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: Published with its FY23 Corporate Reporting is Stockland's first Climate Transition Action Plan. The Plan outlines how Stockland addresses climate change risks and opportunities and delivers on its purpose. The Plan was developed regarding the Science Based Targets Initiative (SBTi) criteria and in response to the Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD).
column20: Climate Transition Action Plan, climate change risk, SBTi

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: Work to reduce the embodied carbon of Stockland's developments is already underway. At Stockland's M_Park development in Sydney, NSW, upfront carbon assessments have been used to identify the largest sources of embodied carbon in its building materials to enable the team to target the most impactful materials.
column20: Upfront carbon assessment, embodied carbon, building material

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: At the Land Lease Communities (LLC), Stockland continued to expand its solar program with new solar systems installed on community centres across its LLC portfolio, including a 15kW solar system on Halcyon Berwick's clubhouse and a 36kW solar system on Haylcon Nirimba's community centre.
column20: Solar program, solar system, community centre

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: A key element of developing assets with leading sustainability credentials is understanding the embodied impact of materials. Stockland performed Materials Flow Analysis and Life Cycle Analysis (LCA) in collaboration with third-party consultants to inform its target setting and identify ways to reduce its embodied carbon impacts. This process involved measuring the quantity of each material used during the construction and operation of buildings and their associated environmental impacts.
column20: Life Cycle Analysis, Materials Flow Analysis, embodied carbon

column7: All of Stockland's senior management are from local communities.

column6: Infrastructure investments and services supported
column7: Stockland spent $271.500 for infrastructure investments in FY23.

column6: Significant indirect economic impacts
Proportion of spending on local suppliers
column13: In FY23, Stockland spent over $4.3m in Indigenous procurement across 24 Supply Nation suppliers. It included spending from Stockland's All-Indigenous Tenders program, which aims to increase Indigenous inclusion in its tender process. Specifically, this has resulted in the appointment of a new national Indigenous stationery supplier, as well as the awarding of contracts to Indigenous businesses and suppliers at multiple construction projects, including Stockland Wetherill Park revitalisation, Stockland Shellharbour food court remix, Stockland Nowra car park and Stockland Wetherill Park Kinchin Lane in NSW.
column20: All-Indigenous Tenders program, Indigenous procurement, stationery supplier

column6: Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
column13: Stockland asks employees to confirm they have read and acknowledged its Code of Conduct upon commencing with Stockland and as part of their annual compliance statement. Stockland promptly investigates any breaches of its Code of Conduct and applies penalties for substantiated breaches up to and including dismissal.
column20: Code of Conduct, compliance statement, substantiated breach

column6: Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
Confirmed incidents of corruption and actions taken
Legal actions for anti-competitive behavior, anti-trust, and monopoly practices
column7: No legal actions for anti-competitive behaviour, anti-trust, or monopoly practices in FY22.

column6: Approach to tax
Tax governance, control, and risk management
Tax governance, control, and risk management
column13: Stockland maintains a Tax Control and Governance Framework (TCGF), reviewed and approved by the Audit Committee, which outlines the principles governing Stockland's tax strategy and risk management policy. The TCGF is consistent with the guidelines published by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) regarding tax risk management and governance processes for large business taxpayers.
column20: Tax Control and Governance Framework, tax strategy, Australian Taxation Office

column6: Stakeholder engagement and management of concerns related to tax
Stakeholder engagement and management of concerns related to tax
column13: As part of Stockland's commitment to tax transparency and demonstrating good corporate citizenship, Stockland has adopted the Australian Federal Government's Voluntary Tax Transparency Code (TTC), which provides a set of principles and minimum standards to guide medium and large businesses on public disclosure of tax information.
column20: Voluntary Tax Transparency Code, tax transparency, public disclosure
